ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Eric is a great, passionate lecturer. I really enjoyed that he's also a practitioner, and is so interested and engaged in the material. I know he has plans to teach this class for a full semester next year and to incorporate more field trips- I wish I could be part of it, but I think the material will be too redundant.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Materials and teaching
The instructor- engaged, passionate, interested, and comfortable chatting in front of the class. He brought in a lot of relevant, real-world examples of his work and the research he's done.
Field trip
Interesting exposure to new material from the perspective of a practitioner
Blew my mind. I had never heard about agroforestry, and the introduction that Eric provided opened up a whole new world for me.

MIssed out on the field trip which I hear is the best part. The lectures were worthwhile and provided a good general overview of the field. Doing independent research on a topic of our own choice was nice too since it allowed us to approach the material from a perspective that we found interesting.
This is a unique course and it is one of the most forward-thinking that I have taken at F&ES. Eric has a wealth of knowledge to share and is incredibly accessible.
Professor is so knowlegeable in the subject that he makes the couse extremetly interesting.
Concise overview of agroforestry practices
The instruction was incredible, and the field trip very inspiring!
Charismatic and motivated lecturer.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More field trips

I wish it was a full semester long, which I know is already going to happen. Additional field trips would also be helpful and well-suited to the material. The most difficult part of this class was the timing for me- 6pm-9pm, which was tough after a full day of class.
Lectures. More discussion or interactions would be helpful. A different format for some of the classes besides a continual lecture each time for three hours would be better.
Perhaps more grounding in theory or current debates in the field of environmental studies. Having this class co-taught with a Yale professor could help provide that more academic perspective.

I would have liked to have seen a little more depth in the treatment of the various mechanisms through which carbon is sequestered in soils and biomass of agroforestry systems. Maybe talking in further depth about quantification challenges faced by the sector. I think this deserves a full class, especially if it is a 3 credit course. Maybe making Nairs piece on methodological challenges required reading?

Enjoyed the articles, but it could have been more valuable to have more targeted response questions. I often felt like I was just writing to meet the word requirement, versus for deeper understanding. Could provide a review summary or would also be interesting to read articles about other agroforestry projects.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
No lab section in this class.
Not much in-class discussion, could have a more institutionalized format for discussion rather than just Q&A with the instructor

I think the lecture heavy format was the right call given the late in the day time slot, when people were more or less spent. If it were earlier in the day I would say some small group discussion would have been a good compliment.
n/a
The field trip was excellent. Seeing a home garden made a lot of difference in understanding the subject.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Agroforestry is what I want to do after I graduate. So, this course taught me how to develop agroforestry and what does it mean by having different tree species
I'm interested in how climate change issues will be incorporated into future international development planning. Agroforestry is a great avenue for achieving multiple development objectives.
Like frosting on the cake.
I am interested in agriculture and food systems.
If there were more classes like this at F&ES I would take them. But there are not.
This course gave me insights of Carbon Sequestration in such a short duration. It will help me formulate agroforestry projects for my country.
It fits well with my work and academic backgrounds in agriculture.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Yes, because I am interested in agroforestry as part of agricultural development
I wanted to better understand the potential for agroforestry systems to address climate change, social justice, food security and other issues around the globe.
To learn more about agroforestry.

Interest in the subject, however "Multi-Functional Carbon Sequestration" is perhaps not the most factual title for the course, given the actual material on the syllabus, the title should emphasize agroforestry and consumption of perennials more
See above. It is one of the limited offerings in practical agricultural knowledge in the program.

Agroforestry is a large sector in my country and rural livelihoods depend on it. This course has enhanced my knowledge on agroforestry and how it can assist in increasing economic capability of farmers while also sequestering carbon and protecting the environment.
To gain new knowledge on agroforestry practices in the tropics.
Learn about agricultural aspects of forestry.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, I learned more about agroforestry
Absolutely.
No, but if I was unfamiliar with agroforesty then it would be an excellent course for learning an overview about the topic.
Mostly, yes
Exceeded expectations.
Yes. I learned some new things about the state of the field, its limitations, and exciting possibilities.
Yes!
Yes. The lectures were so insightful and the field trip added more value to them.
Yes, pretty much.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N?A
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take the course!
Take it! It's interesting, the professor is great, and the work load emphasizes practical learning, not busywork.

Take the course if it does not interfere with any other courses yo are considering and especially if you are new to learning about ethnobotany or agroforestry. If you are already very versed in the topic, it might not benefit you as much.
Interesting introduction to a subject, relatively small workload considering it is only a 1 credit course. Valuable exposure to a topic that differs from other Yale offerings
Take it and make the most of it.
Highly recommended!
Six classes and bag full of knowledge. Make the most of it. The Professor goes way beyond to help in researches related to this subject. Make the best use of his knowledge and resources.
